comments.html: 2014 starts and ends with winter ;) I hope we'll see it in early 2014.
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html: FCS in winter 2014? Is it that far away? Was expecting some kind of release a couple of months from now.
comments.name: Anonymous

comments.html: Yeah. I really hope Cisco does not mess this up. Watching Hitchhikers guide to OnePK and would be really useful to have VIRL and development in one environment. That would really help for us engineers that need to learn some programming as well.
comments.name: Anonymous

comments.html:
Yes. They said you'll be able to add your VMs to the environment (servers ...) as well as interact with the outside world through the usual "physical" Ethernet interfaces.

Keep in mind that CML is nothing else than a single-host OpenStack deployment - anything you could do in OpenStack you could (theoretically) do with CML.
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html:
Will you be able to attach the virtual network on your laptop/PC via VIRL to a real network ?

Say you have a lab with 10 real routers. Running IS-IS. Now you attach your PC, which has a 100 virtual (virl) routers. Suddenly your IS-IS network has 110 routers, consisting of a combination of real and virtual routers. This could be a nice way to check interoperability.
comments.name: Henk

comments.html: All of the above?
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html: Actually you could contact the Cisco accounting team, they do disclose the preliminary pricing information. And yes, everyone would get some. It's not too cheap though.
comments.name: Anonymous

comments.html: I'm sure they are tight lipped on pricing / licensing specifics...but any hints as to who they expect a typical customer for this might be?  Large enterprises/SP's, individuals running labs at home, etc?
comments.name: Oliver

comments.html: We've been running 70+ router emulation environments via Dynamips for some years to verify routing policy changes etc. hooked up to physical test kit when necessary. The ability to have a Cisco provided solution running on Cisco Hardware (C Series Servers) that is fully supported is really exciting. I'll certainly be hassling my Account Manager for more info.
comments.name: Dean Smith

comments.html:
The behavior also known as Infinite Monkey Theorem ;)

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infinite_monkey_theorem

Sweet dreams!
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html: sure but seriously, if your a skilled engineer but say not expert on MPLS TE on the IOS-XR routers. Now it seems like with a few days on VIRL you can be therefore it can probably be a good way to reduce consultancy costs if you already have a team of strong engineers who need to learn a new technology.
comments.name: Chris Gray

comments.html:
If you are fluent in the nuances of MPLS TE (technology details and design challenges) then VIRL will definitely give you hands-on experience you need prior to deployment - so you'll be able to do the deployment yourself instead of using consultants.

If you think VIRL will give you design expertise, then my original comment still applies ;) See also RFC 1925 section 2.4
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html: no more need for consultant firms, the customer can play on VIRL until he gets his design right.
comments.name: Anonymous

comments.html: RFC 1925 section 2.4 - Haha! Good one, haven't seen that before :-)
comments.name: DanC

comments.html: Still on the fence about this solution of short-cutting the forwarding plane versus what Juniper is doing with things like Virtual MX.   With the VMX Juniper is actually emulating the PFE, so the throughput is terrible, only around 1kpps, and it takes a lot of CPU resources, but it truly tests both control and forwarding plane, including things like hashing.
comments.name: Anonymous

comments.html: Any updates for VIRL as 5.1 released and they said VIRL will be with 5.2 release...
comments.name: Anonymous

comments.html:
Each virtual routers are basically VMs orchestrated via OpenStack via Java based GUI called VMMaestro ,copyrighted Cisco (not Oracles as many bloggers suggested). Wish bloggers would stop blogging based on others blog. :-)
Networking is through virtual switches, tap / tunnels,so no reason you cannot connect them to a physical box .
comments.name: Jason Wong

comments.html: Ivan, Have you heard any further updates on this matter? Thanks,
comments.name: Anonymous

comments.html: At Cisco Live in Milano last week they had a demo of CML running that you could try out in the walk in labs and also on display at the learingnetwork booth. They're releasing two versions of it one for private use that would cost aprox $100 and with a 15 device limit and then a corporate version with no limits but the guy i talked to didn't know the price for that one yet.
comments.name: Haara

comments.html: Well! How can I forget about RFC 1925 section 2.4. What's about that quote which was too common at that time? "Some things in life can never be totally appreciated or understood until experienced firsthand".
comments.name: Unknown

comments.html: Is it true that NX-OS implementaion on VIRL still does not support any of the data centre features, like OTV, vPC, LACP? I am not a user, but thinking of moving from GNS3 to VIRL. And then this came up...
comments.name: Anonymous
